docs.lead_paragraph: A NEW law took effect in the state on Oct. 1 that bolsters nursing mothers' rights in the workplace. The law requires that employers provide employees who are nursing mothers with a private place -- other than a toilet stall -- to express milk for their babies. It was passed with no significant opposition as women's groups, unions and many employers supported the legislation's goals of protecting the health of babies and promoting employee productivity and loyalty.

headline.main: For Nursing Mothers, Their Own Space

docs.abstract: Article on new law in Connecticut, effective October 1, that requires employers to provide workers who are nursing mothers with private place, other than toilet stall, to breast feed their babies; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE federal government has said it will spend billions of dollars to combat bioterrorism in our midst. But how much money will Americans waste first? There is no question that news reports of a baby and others being exposed to anthrax in the middle of Manhattan are terrifying. In some cases, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is recommending that people who have no symptoms and have not tested positive for anthrax exposure take antibiotics as a precaution.
docs.abstract: Jennifer Steinhauer column on health risks of taking antibiotics as precaution against anthrax and financial damage done when people visit hospitals and doctors as precautionary measure (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In that distant world far, far away that was America before Sept. 11, much was written about how the Internet and cable television were creating a newly fragmented, decentralized world -- a culturally splintered world of niche marketing, special-interest publications and identity politics. As one 1990's survey of Internet politics concluded, virtual communities ''resemble the semiprivate spaces of modern health clubs more than the public spaces of agoras'': ''instead of meeting to discuss and debate issues of common concern to the society, members of these virtual communities meet largely to promote their own interests and to reinforce their own like-mindedness.'' As a result, the cultural critic David Shenk wrote in his book ''Data Smog,'' ''It appears that rather than our world becoming a cozy village, we are instead retreating into an electronic Tower of Babel, a global skyscraper. Instead of gathering us into the town square, the new information technology clusters us into social cubicles. There are fewer central spaces, and not even a common channel.''

headline.main: Fear, the New Virus Of a Connected Era

docs.abstract: Critic's Notebook by Michiko Kakutani notes that terrorist attacks of Sept 11 unified nation in obvious ways, but also created ripple effect that moved across nation, revealing just how interconnected country really is; says because all of America was affected by events of Sept 11, Internet and 24-hour cable news shows quickly assumed role of electronic town halls; says these forms of communication have now become national forums for expression of anxiety; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With her 7-week-old baby nursing at her breast, Dr. Sandra Steingraber spoke at a conference held recently in New York to address an important issue: the presence of low levels of chemical residues in breast milk. Dr. Steingraber, an ecologist and a visiting assistant professor at Cornell University's program on breast cancer and environmental risk factors, described breast-feeding as ''a very exquisite communion between myself and my child'' -- but also a transfer of chemicals.

headline.main: Research Is Urged for Healthier Breast Milk

docs.abstract: Research is urged for healthier breast milk, in light of new concerns about chemicals in milk that may be transmitted to babies (M)
